title: What is the Symbolic Meaning of King Arthur's Retreat to Avalon?
first_phrase: This text is about the legendary King Arthur and his retreat to Avallon. The events leading up to his retreat are described as tragic, and his retreat is seen as the latent becoming of a principle or function. The figure of King Arthur represents the "polar dominator" or "king of the world" whose historical element is infused with the supernatural. The symbolism of the Round Table and Arthur's palace being at the center of the world is associated with solar and polar symbolism. The supernatural features of King Arthur are embodied in Merlin, his inseparable advisor. The final 200 tokens describe King Arthur's knights searching for the Holy Grail with the order to "Who is the head, let him be the bridge."
content: Il palazzo di Re Artù — come il Mitgard, la residenza luminosa degli Asen, degli « eroi divi- ni_ » nordici — è costruito nel « centro del mondo » — in medio mundi constructum. Secondo alcuni testi, esso gira intorno ad un punto centrale: gira, come nen'« isola bianca » qvetadvipa — ricordata dagli indoeuropei d'Asia, nella terra iperborea il cui dio è il solare Vishnu, gira lo swa- stika; come « l'isola di vetro » celtico-nordica — un fac- simile dell'Avallon — gira; come la ruota fatale del cakra- vara, del « Re del Mondo » ariano, gira. I tratti sovranna- turali, « magici », propri a questa figura s'incarnano, per così dire, in Myrddhin, cioè in Merlino, consigliere insepa- rabile di Re Artù, che è, in fondo, meno un essere da lui distinto che non la figurazione personificata della parte sovrannaturale dello stesso Artù. La cavalleria di Artù an- drà alla ricerca del Graal. La cavalleria di Artù, che reclu- ta i suoi membri da tutte le patrie, ha per parola d'ordine: « Chi è capo, ci sia da ponte ».
last_phrase: In conclusion, the palace of King Arthur, like other mythical and legendary places such as Swastika Island and the Glass Island, is said to be situated at the center of the world, embodying supernatural qualities. The quest for the Holy Grail adds to the mystique of Arthurian legend, and the motto of his diverse group of knights, "He who is chief, let him bridge," speaks to the idea of connectivity and bridging between worlds, which is reflected in the etymology of the word "pontifex." The significance of these legends resonates across cultures and time, reminding us of the enduring power of storytelling and the human need for connection and meaning.
